bibl.title: Letter from I.T. Haig to Philip Showalter Hench, September 12, 1940

div1.p: Haig reports that he cannot date the tree from the photo, but refers Hench to a forester who may be able to help.

div1.head: Letter from I.T. Haig to Philip Showalter Hench, September 12, 1940
div1.opener:
YOURS IN TRUST
WE MUST
PROTECT IT
FROM FIRE
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE
FOREST SERVICE
U S
WASHINGTON
September 12, 1940.
FORMATION
quiries
Dr. P. S. Hench,
Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minnesota.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p: We have your letter of August 28.

In temperate regions the annual rings of a cross section
of the main stem of a tree formed by differences in growth during
summer and winter give a fairly reliable indication of tree age.
In tropical regions on the other hand, these rings, if they are
present and distinguishable, may be unreliable as an indication
of age because they are formed by factors of irregular occurrence,
such as wet and dry spells. Furthermore, I am rather doubtful
whether it would be possible to tell the age of the flamboyant
tree from a photograph. However, our Tropical Forest Experiment
Station in Puerto Rico may be able to assist you in this matter.
Mr. Bevan, Director of the station, is acquainted with many of the
foresters in the tropical region and may be able to put you in
touch with a reliable man who could examine the tree for you. I
am therefore forwarding your letter to this station and you may ex-
pect to hear from Mr. Bevan in the near future.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, I. T. HAIG, Chief,
Division of Forest Management Research.
